item.content:
Letting your terminal better to work

Hello there. Let’s configuration a beauty and productive terminal. This is not a detailed tutorial. I will leave here links and some commands on how I set up my terminal. It’s easy, just follow in order

Terminator

Step by step

1. Install Zsh

You need to install a different shell. But calm. Nothing will change in relation to bash

Access this page. This will help you with installation for your Linux distro.


2. Install Oh My Zsh

To next step install Oh My Zsh. It will let the Zsh more customizable.

Run on terminal:

sh -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ohmyzsh/ohmyzsh/master/tools/install.sh)"

3. Dracula Theme

I did choose Dracula for my dark theme. You can choose a theme of your preference.
Dark theme for Terminator


4. Theme shell Spaceship

Spaceship is easy to install. Just run on terminal:

git clone https://github.com/spaceship-prompt/spaceship-prompt.git "$ZSH_CUSTOM/themes/spaceship-prompt" --depth=1

And create symlink to your custom theme directory:

ln -s "$ZSH_CUSTOM/themes/spaceship-prompt/spaceship.zsh-theme" "$ZSH_CUSTOM/themes/spaceship.zsh-theme"

Active Spaceship to your major theme. Edit ~/.zshrc and find ZSH_THEME

ZSH_THEME="spaceship"


For more about Spaceship: GitHub - Spaceship


5. Aditional Configurations

In the end of file ~/.zshrc add the content below:

SPACESHIP_PROMPT_ORDER=(
  user          # Username section
  dir           # Current directory section
  host          # Hostname section
  git           # Git section (git_branch + git_status)
  node
  rust
  docker
  hg            # Mercurial section (hg_branch  + hg_status)
  exec_time     # Execution time
  line_sep      # Line break
  vi_mode       # Vi-mode indicator
  jobs          # Background jobs indicator
  exit_code     # Exit code section
  char          # Prompt character
)
SPACESHIP_USER_SHOW=always
SPACESHIP_PROMPT_ADD_NEWLINE=false
SPACESHIP_CHAR_SYMBOL="‚ùØ"
SPACESHIP_CHAR_SUFFIX=" "

SPACESHIP_RUST_SYMBOL="ü¶Ä  "
SPACESHIP_RUST_COLOR=red

You can customize everything! See the documentation in the previous step.


6. Plugins

Finally we go to install some plugins. To manage the plugins we will use a Zinit fork. To install run on terminal:

sh -c "$(curl -fsSL https://git.io/zinit-install)"

With the installation completed, edit ~/.zshrc and add the content below in end of file:

zinit light zdharma-continuum/fast-syntax-highlighting
zinit light zsh-users/zsh-autosuggestions
zinit light zsh-users/zsh-completions

Save the file, close the terminal and open again. It install the three plugins. That do:

  • color highlight
  • autosuggestions of commands
  • autocomplete improved

7. Terminal VSCode [Bonus]

To activate and use this new terminal in VSCode edit your settings.json and add this instruction:

"terminal.integrated.defaultProfile.linux": "zsh"


The end

Liked this terminal? Clean, fast and productive. You can use the comments area to suggest tips and screenshots of your terminal.

item.content:
The Planning:

I started a new project. Unnamed yet, but I already know about what will be. It looks a bit silly but I want to do a money manager. An application that you can add entries for expenses and incomes.

How I started? Planning! I am planning the database. I intend to use PostgreSQL for my database.

I am using dbdiagram.io to create my schemas

dbdiagram.io

On the left side I wrote in code what I want to represent in my tables. The rest of the screen is a graphical representation of the tables.

Very much references:

Ever you see “_id” on column is a reference to another table. The name that comes before is the name of the other table.

The representation in code is:

Ref: accounts.user_id > users.id

Table.Foreign Key > Other Table.Primary Key

Technologies:

I want to use in this project:

  • Elixir for backend
  • GraphQl for API
  • PostgreSQL for database
  • ReactJS for frontend
  • […] for Mobile

Go Up!

This is the first post of a saga. I want to documentation all status of project here and explain details about each process executed. When the project reaches maturity will be available in GitHub for viewing and contribution. Let’s work and do something different happen.

See you!


The link to Part 2 will be updated when available

item.content:
When I bought a Keychron K2 I knew it would work in Windows and Mac, but I use Linux. But it‚Äôs just a keyboard‚Ä¶ it should work.

Well… It works! But on my OS Arch Linux with Gnome had a little problem. The FN keys didn‚Äôt work perfectly. Actually the FN keys were for MacOS, not Windows.

How I fixed:

  • Use the switch on side of keyboard to change to Windows mode
  • Hold Fn + X + L for 4 seconds to set the key row to Function mode

Type in the terminal:

echo 0 | sudo tee /sys/module/hid_apple/parameters/fnmode

When doing this your keyboard should work perfectly.

With a small detail: to persist this change you need to add a module option for hid_apple

echo "options hid_apple fnmode=0" | sudo tee -a /etc/modprobe.d/hid_apple.conf

Important!

Now you need to rebuild your initramfs if hid_apple module is included.

  • Ubuntu: sudo update-initramfs -u
  • Arch: mkinitcpio -P

Good! After reboot your OS don’t will go miss this configuration and your FN keys will work as if it were Windows.


Source: Mike Shade
